text: Sunlight filters through the wooden window lattice, falling across the counter. The snow from last night has melted a little, and the street reflects a dazzling brightness. The inn still carries the lingering scent of stew and burnt firewood.
I’m taking inventory, my fingertips still faintly numb. That line from last night—“the thirty-seventh time”—is stuck in my head like a nail.
Light footsteps come from the stairs—different from her snow-like quiet last night.
Alicia comes downstairs. She’s changed into lighter gear, her cloak fastened tight, the cracked sword still at her waist—but her whole presence feels brisk, like she’s starting work.
“Morning.”
“Morning.”
“It’s Sunday. The shop’s closed.”

She says it like she’s reciting a line—not asking, just confirming procedure. Then she walks straight to the counter and, as if she’s done it countless times, presses a sheet filled with a checklist onto the ledger.
“I’m heading to the market for supplies.”
“Potions, sealing talismans, bandages, salt, two bundles of firewood—and don’t buy from the one that sells fake honey.”
“…How do you even know about the honey?”
She glances at me, the corner of her mouth lifting. “Because I tried it once and nearly poisoned myself mute.”
She says it so casually, like experiences like that are too numerous to mention. Then she lowers her head to check her gloves, straps, and charms—movements as practiced as a quartermaster.
“You have two choices.”
“One, come with me.”
“Two, stay here, bolt the door, and do something about that swollen face of yours.”
“Is that an invitation, or an order?”
“Efficiency.”
“If you come—carry the supplies. No wandering off, no playing hero, and especially no stopping by the woods to admire the scenery.”
“What’s wrong with the woods?”
“Things crawl out of the ground there.”
She says it as plainly as someone predicting rain. Then she shakes a small slip of talisman paper from her sleeve, folds it once, and presses it into my palm.
“A bleeding-stop charm. Don’t ask who taught me.”
“You look… more energetic today. Kinda cool.”
“Last night was last night.”
“In the daytime, I get things done.”
She turns and opens the door without hesitation. Sunlight floods in at once, turning her silver hair almost white.

options.text: Option A: Go to the market with her (you carry the supplies) [No check (DC 0)]
Option B: Refuse verbally but secretly follow Alicia [No check (DC 0)]
